thread.title: Ja'Ron runs wild in win over Coppell: Wilson gashes Cowboy defense for 350 yards, 5 touchdowns
thread.title_full: Ja'Ron runs wild in win over Coppell: Wilson gashes Cowboy defense for 350 yards, 5 touchdowns

author: Justin Thomas, jthomas@starlocalmedia.com
title: Ja'Ron runs wild in win over Coppell: Wilson gashes Cowboy defense for 350 yards, 5 touchdowns
text:
Photo courtesy of Glenn Gunn COPPELL FOOTBALL 
Coppell running back Brandon Rice, left, had 92 yards on 17 carries in Friday’s 49-14 loss to Euless Trinity.  38 am Ja'Ron runs wild in win over Coppell: Wilson gashes Cowboy defense for 350 yards, 5 touchdowns   
COPPELL — A week of preparation and three weather delays Friday wasn’t enough time for Coppell’s football team to scheme a way to slow Trinity running back Ja’Ron Wilson. 
The senior racked up 350 yards and five touchdowns on 23 carries as the state-ranked Trojans cruised past the Cowboys on the road, 49-14. 
“If it was dry, they’re just as good,” said Mike DeWitt, Coppell head coach. “They’re big up front, they’re very well-coached and [Wilson] is one of the best backs I’ve coached against in a long time.” 
Wilson posted 154 yards in the first quarter alone as Trinity grabbed an early 14-0 advantage before both teams were forced to vacate the field for a lightning delay that lasted 85 minutes — the third stoppage of the night. 
Wilson picked up right where he left off when play resumed, darting 59 yards for his third score of the night as the Trojans took a commanding 21-0 lead. 
Coppell would answer with its first points of the night when quarterback Brady McBride found a jumping Josh Fink in the corner of the end zone for a 23-yard touchdown. Fink had six catches on the drive alone and finished with 10 catches for 127 yards, including a 47-yard reception in the fourth quarter that led to a 36-yard scoring grab for Jarel McGill. 
McBride finished with 187 passing yards and two scores to go with 48 yards on the ground. 
Brandon Rice paced the Coppell rushing attack with 92 yards on 17 carries. 
While Coppell moved the ball effectively, a trio of turnovers proved costly. 
The first, and interception, occurred in the red zone after Trinity fumbled on the game’s first play from scrimmage. The latter, a fumble, also came in Trinity territory as the Cowboys were on the move and trailing at the time, 7-0. Later in the fourth, Trinity’s Kader Kohou came up with an interception in the end zone. 
“I don’t have a crystal ball, but you sure would have liked to got points there,” DeWitt said of the first turnover. 
Otherwise, it was Trinity and its vaunted ground game controlling the contest. In addition to Wilson’s big night, Javontay Powe chipped in 118 yards on nine carries as the Trojans totaled 539 yards for the game — their third consecutive outing with more than 500 yards rushing. 
“They’re really good,” DeWitt said. “They’re good up front and they have a great scheme. They’re blocking down and arching guys and so you have to try to be plus-one. And when you are, then you have to try to tackle a really good back. Hats off to them. I think they’re going to win a lot of football games.” 
Coppell will look to tighten the screws defensively at 7:30 p.m. Friday at Colleyville Heritage. 
“I was proud of how the kids battled not just here on the field, but mentally having to come out and go back and come out and so on,” DeWitt said. “We’re a tough team and we’ll go regroup and get some rest and get ready for Colleyville (starting) tomorrow.”
